event_identity.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about what the event is called, its tagline, which edition it is, and where to find the official website.
event_identity.name: LA Hacks 2025

start_datetime.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about when the hackathon starts, the opening date and time, or when participants should arrive.

end_datetime.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about when the hackathon ends, the closing date and time, or the duration of the event.

hacking_start_datetime.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about when hacking officially begins, when participants may start coding, or when the build period opens.
hacking_start_datetime.note: Hacking begins after the opening ceremony concludes.

submission_deadline.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about when projects must be submitted, the Devpost deadline, or when hacking ends.
submission_deadline.note: All project submissions must be finalized on Devpost before this time. Late submissions will not be accepted.

check_in.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about where and when to check in, what to bring for check-in, or the registration process upon arrival.
what_to_bring: Valid student ID or government-issued photo ID
Confirmation email or QR code from registration
Sleeping bag or blanket (optional, for overnight stays)

venue.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about where the hackathon is held, the address, specific rooms or floors, or parking information.
venue.parking: Structure 8 (Lot 8) on Westwood Plaza; flat $12/day weekend rate. Street parking also available on Westwood Blvd.

schedule.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about the event schedule, what happens at a specific time, or the order of activities throughout the hackathon.

items.title: Check-In & Registration
items.description: Pick up your badge, swag bag, and wristband.

items.title: Dinner
items.description: Opening dinner — burritos and quesadillas from Chronic Tacos.

items.title: Opening Ceremony
items.description: Welcome remarks, sponsor spotlights, track announcements, and keynote speaker.

items.title: Hacking Begins
items.description: Official start of the 36-hour hacking period.

items.title: Breakfast
items.description: Bagels, pastries, fruit, and coffee.

items.title: Lunch
items.description: Catered lunch — pizza from 800 Degrees.

items.title: Dinner
items.description: Catered dinner — Korean BBQ bowls.

items.title: Midnight Snack
items.description: Late-night ramen and boba.

items.title: Breakfast
items.description: Breakfast burritos and coffee.

items.title: Hacking Ends / Submission Deadline
items.description: All projects must be submitted on Devpost by this time.

items.title: Project Demos & Judging
items.description: Teams present demos at their tables; judges rotate through.

items.title: Lunch
items.description: Final lunch — sandwiches and salads.

items.title: Closing Ceremony & Awards
items.description: Prize announcements, sponsor awards, and closing remarks.

team_requirements.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about team size limits, whether solo participation is allowed, or how to register a team.
team_requirements.notes: All team members must be registered hackers. Teams must be finalized and registered on Devpost before submitting a project.

eligibility.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about who is eligible to participate, age requirements, whether high school students can attend, or guest policies.
requirements: Must be a currently enrolled college or university student
Must be at least 18 years old
International students with valid student visas are welcome
High school students are not eligible to compete but may attend as observers with a guest pass
eligibility.guest_policy: Each registered hacker may bring one non-competing guest. Guests must sign in at the front desk and wear a guest badge at all times.

tracks_and_themes.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about competition tracks, themes, or what types of projects are being built.

items.name: AI for Good
items.description: Build AI-powered solutions that address social, environmental, or humanitarian challenges.

items.name: FinTech
items.description: Innovate in financial services, personal finance, banking, or economic empowerment.

items.name: Web3 & Blockchain
items.description: Create decentralized applications, smart contracts, or explore emerging blockchain use cases.

items.name: Health & Wellness
items.description: Improve physical or mental health through technology.

items.name: Open Innovation
items.description: Build anything — no theme restriction. Creativity and impact are the only requirements.

prizes.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about prize amounts, what the winners receive, or how prizes are distributed across categories.

tiers.description: Awarded to the single best overall project across all tracks.
Awarded to the second-best overall project.
Best project in the AI for Good track.
Best project in the FinTech track.
Best project in the Web3 & Blockchain track.
Best project in the Health & Wellness track.
Awarded to the best project from a team where all members are first-time hackathon participants.
Best use of the Claude API in a project.
Best use of Google Cloud services.

judging_criteria.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about how projects are evaluated, what judges look for, or what scoring rubric is used.

criteria.name: Innovation
criteria.description: How original and creative is the idea? Does it address a real problem in a novel way?

criteria.name: Technical Complexity
criteria.description: How technically challenging is the implementation? Does it demonstrate strong engineering?

criteria.name: Impact
criteria.description: What is the potential real-world impact? Who benefits and how significantly?

criteria.name: Presentation & Demo
criteria.description: How clearly is the project explained? Does the demo work and communicate the value effectively?

judging_criteria.judge_rotation: Judges rotate to each team table during the 2-hour demo period. Each team presents for approximately 5 minutes.

submission_requirements.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about what must be submitted for a project to be eligible, what the Devpost submission should include, or whether a GitHub link is required.
required: Devpost project page (must be submitted before 9:00 AM Sunday)
Project title and description (what it does, how it was built)
Link to public GitHub repository with working code
2-minute demo video (uploaded to YouTube or Vimeo, unlisted is fine)
List of all team members (must match registered hackers)
optional: Slide deck (PDF or Google Slides link)

workshops.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about workshops, tech talks, learning sessions, or what skills are being taught at the event.

items.title: Intro to Hackathons
items.description: Tips for first-time hackers: how to pick an idea, form a team, and scope a project.

items.title: Building with the Claude API
items.description: Hands-on intro to Claude's API: prompting techniques, tool use, and building agents.

items.title: Deploying ML Models with Google Cloud
items.description: Deploy a trained ML model as a REST API on Vertex AI in under 30 minutes.

items.title: Smart Contracts 101
items.description: Write, test, and deploy your first Solidity smart contract on a testnet.

items.title: Product Design Sprint
items.description: Rapid prototyping with Figma: go from idea to clickable mockup in 60 minutes.

sponsors.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about who is sponsoring the hackathon, sponsorship tiers, or what sponsors are offering to participants.

tiers.benefits_to_hackers: Google Cloud credits ($300/team), dedicated mentors, prize category
API credits, workshops, sponsored prize categories

resources_and_apis.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about what tools, APIs, cloud credits, hardware, or SDKs are available for hackers to use.

items.details: $300 in GCP credits per team. Activate at the Google Cloud booth in Bruin Plaza.
Free API credits for hackathon use. Visit the Anthropic booth or go to https://console.anthropic.com and use promo code LAHACKS2025.
Free M10 cluster for the duration of the hackathon. Sign up at https://mongodb.com/try.
Free Pro plan for 6 months for all participants. Use the Vercel booth QR code to activate.
Raspberry Pis, Arduino kits, sensors, and cameras available to borrow. Located at Table H in the hacking floor. First-come, first-served.

meals_and_food.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about food, meals, when food is served, meal times, what time is lunch/dinner/breakfast, when is the next meal, whether a meal has already passed, what is being served, where to get food, or dietary accommodations. The schedule lists every meal with date, time, location, and menu.

schedule.dietary_notes: Vegetarian and vegan options available. Gluten-free tortillas on request.
Gluten-free bagels available. Dairy-free milk alternatives provided.
Vegetarian pizzas available. Gluten-free crust on request (limited supply).
Vegetarian ramen available. Dairy-free boba milk options.
Vegan, vegetarian, and gluten-free wraps available.

meals_and_food.general_note: If you have severe allergies, please notify an organizer at check-in so we can accommodate you.

wifi_and_connectivity.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about the WiFi network name, password, internet connectivity, or how to get technical support for connectivity issues.
wifi_and_connectivity.coverage: Full venue coverage including Ackerman Union and Pauley Pavilion
wifi_and_connectivity.it_support: Visit the Help Desk at Table A near the main entrance, or message #tech-help on the event Slack.
wifi_and_connectivity.backup_network: UCLA_WiFi (eduroam available for students with institutional credentials)

code_of_conduct.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about rules of conduct, prohibited behavior, what items are banned, or how to report an incident.
code_of_conduct.summary: LA Hacks is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form.
prohibited: Harassment, discrimination, or intimidation of any kind
Sharing or displaying sexually explicit or violent material
Alcohol or illegal substances on venue premises
code_of_conduct.reporting: Report incidents to any organizer wearing a blue staff shirt, visit the organizer table near check-in, or email conduct@lahacks.com. All reports are handled confidentially.

contact_and_support.semantic_description: Use this section to answer questions about how to contact organizers, where to get help, the Slack workspace, or emergency contacts.
contact_and_support.help_desk_location: Table A, Ackerman Grand Ballroom Lobby (staffed 24/7 during the event)
contact_and_support.medical_emergency: Call 911 or go to the nearest organizer for first-aid

faq.semantic_description: Use this section to answer common questions that do not fit neatly into another category, including questions about sleeping, laptops, travel reimbursements, etc.

items.question: Can I start working on my project before the hackathon?
items.answer: No. All code must be written during the hacking period (after 9:00 PM Friday). Using pre-existing libraries, frameworks, and open-source code is allowed, but the core project must be built at the hackathon.

items.question: Is there a place to sleep?
items.answer: Yes. Pauley Pavilion is designated as the sleeping area. Bring a sleeping bag or blanket. The venue is open 24/7 throughout the event.

items.question: Will travel reimbursements be provided?
items.answer: We are not offering travel reimbursements this year. However, carpooling coordination is available in the #travel channel on Slack.

items.question: Can I work on multiple tracks?
items.answer: Yes, but you may only submit one project. That project will be evaluated for all tracks it is entered into.

items.question: What happens if I miss the submission deadline?
items.answer: Late submissions will not be considered for prizes. Make sure your Devpost submission is complete before 9:00 AM on Sunday.

items.question: Do I need to bring my own hardware?
items.answer: You need to bring your own laptop and charger. Additional hardware (Raspberry Pis, Arduinos, sensors) is available at the Hardware Lab (Table H) on a first-come, first-served basis.

items.question: Is there parking available?
items.answer: Yes. Structure 8 (Lot 8) on Westwood Plaza charges a flat $12/day rate on weekends. Street parking is also available on Westwood Blvd.
